question_text: Is it doable to train LLMs locally with 54 novels of a given author?
answer_item_1: If your goal is to understand how LLMs work, Build a Large Language Model from scratch by Sebastian Raschka is a good starting point.
answer_item_2: Here are a few tips to get you started: Don't use C++, use python for deep learning
answer_item_3: There are several machine learning frameworks like PyTorch and TensorFlow.
answer_item_4: These answers provided are all good, I only wanted to add that as far as C++ and machine learning goes, there exists LibTorch

question_text: Why do we expect AI to reason instantly when humans require years of lived experience?
answer_item_1: Why do we expect AI to reason instantly when humans require years of lived experience? Many reasons:
answer_item_2: This is an interesting question. I think we expect AI to reason more quickly because we can accelerate the experience-equivalent in their training.
answer_item_3: A neural network in its initial state does not have the ability to reason.
answer_item_4: This is a frame challenge because I don't think we do expect AI models to be able to reason instantly.
answer_item_5: Because we've learned for years that this is how computers work.
answer_item_6: Because AI doesn't take time to learn
answer_item_8: Because we stuff centuries worth of information into them during training.
